p: Although methane production is important in maintaining ruminal environment redox balance by providing a pathway for the excess pyruvate ( 112), it decreases the amount of ME obtained from a diet ( 69), hence, increasing energy required for meat production. The decrease in the concentration of methane produced may reduce atmospheric greenhouse gases and increase feed utilization efficiency as its emissions represent about 10% of gross energy loss from feed intake ( 120). Thus, reduction in methane emissions might maintain or improve animal performance by conserving energy which is redirected to animal growth ( 1). The limited available in vivo studies on antimethogenic effects of hemp by-products on animal performance warrants further research.
